Bottiglia 33 CL. Nel bicchiere è perfettamente limpida con una schiuma abbondante ma poco persistente, il malto si fa sentire nell’aroma e anche nel palato con un leggerissimo amaricato nel finale. Corpo acquoso con una carbonazione alta. Per me è no.
Bottle. Clear deep golden color, medium white head. Aroma of papery straw. Taste is paper, subtle white pepper. Plain.

chiaramente industriale, alla vista è giallo limpidissima con una schiuma abbondante ma evanescente. al naso un filo di lievito e niente di più (da una lager nn m aspetto aromi esageratamente esplosivi ma nemmeno una piattezza del genere). In fles van 0.5 liter. Geel van kleur met een matige schuimkop . eerste smaak beleving leek het op wiesnfest bier maar snel daarna stort de smaak in.
0.5l bottle at home. Light copper colour. White head. First impression : watery, bubbles, little bitter, little citrus.
Pours a clear golden color with a thick white head. The aroma is quite bready. The taste is rather sweet white bread/cereal. The drink ability for this beer is high and it is very refreshing.

Munich lager de 4,9 % abv. Couleur jaune très très léger.
Clarté nette, pure comme la loi de pureté.
Bulles très sommaires, juste quelques grosses à l’unité !!
Mousse qui n’est qu’un nappage diaphane.
Arômes de lager, pils, maïs, houblon.
1ère bouche douce sur du malt clair, pointe de blé.
Arrière-bouche tendre, mais plate.
2ème sur la pils avec un houblon de bas niveau.
Arrière-bouche de café du peuple.
3ème où le maïs adoucit l’ensemble.
La longueur donne un peu de moelleux.
L’alcool est du type lager, tout à fait inopérant.
En finale on rejoint la pils chinoise.
CONCLUSION : une lager qui tient à peu près la route, sans exagérer bien sûr le propos,
mais elle a quelques côtés acceptables.
Malty and hoppy Dortmunder lager that may not be so well balanced, but good nonetheless.

50cl bb03/2015, Edeka. Dank cardboard and soggy grain in the nose announce that this is a mug-sized chugger: taste corroborates this fear by being almost wholly devoid of hop nor specific pale malt character, offering mostly old straw and a sogged bready sweetness with a massive sticky sourdough edge conjuring up sticky Vitamalz. Gulpable and yet less than refreshing.
Smooth, bitter hell. Not earth shattering by any means, but still a solid hell.
Very good beer overall. Pours a very bright golden color, very clear. Small white head. Just the right bitterness and hops. Crisp. Awesome.
the aroma is malty and herbal with hints of grain and hop... the taste is malty, clear and refreshening, with smooth hoppy bitterness... spicy dry aftertaste... classic Bavarian beer...

12 oz. bottle from BevMo. Hard to believe they could continue to sell something this bad. The nose is sort of bready and cereal like with a skunky note. Taste is unbalanced to the sweet side with no discernible hops. Not crisp. Very disappointing...

Clear pale golden colour, white head. Malty aroma and flavour, light bitter. Malty finish.

so, had a few Helles brews last night, and this was the clear winner. paulaner has it down, nice lemon aroma, slightly sweet. smooth and refreshing.

The beer I think of when I think ’Germany’, and I hope no one holds that against me. It was enjoyable to have there, but I had already enjoyed it before (and after) my trips there. In truth, there is nothing overly special about the brew, as it is a relatively simple style of beer, but it is presented exceptionally well. I find that other German lagers from larger brewers tend to become almost muddled, and resemble the macro lagers that they are a little too much (a shame). Paulaner still has a distinct aroma, flavour, and palate that I believes serves as evidence of their quality ingredients. There is no mistaking the typical bready/yeasty aroma of the beer, and the flavour is the refreshing blend of fresh bread, grass, and subdued but present hops that one looks for in this kind of beer. The finish is very clean, and there are no rough edges. If you’re on the lookout for a quality introduction to a classic German beer style that is affordable and accessible, this is your best bet.

Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass zippy, nice head. Starts mild but not washy, fine malty, light spicy. Light fruity notes of apricot. Finish still mild, malty, light dry background. Well balanced finish. Not bad!

The best known Münchener helles, since the early 20th century. Light yellowish white, regular, dense but eventually opening foam, light golden blonde colour, clear. Soft and pure malt sweetness in the nose, chamomille, honey, biscuit, flowery hops. Clean and crisp malt taste, light sweetness, tingling like mineral water, the good quality of the brewing water is clear and plays an important role in lagers like this; elegant, mild spicy hop bitterishness in the finish with a sourish touch. Well-made, appetizing and thirst-quenching, unambitious like any good Helles should be. Exemplary for its style.

From the bottle to the glass.  There goes that Euro-lager aroma again.  I can’t really pinpoint it, but I love it. The best I can do is damp, stone, earthy, and fresh. (no moldiness whatsoever) Maybe a bit herbal. Some malt comes out after the head fades away.  Looks pale straw golden with nice head.  Taste is fairly neutral in terms of sweetness/bitterness/sourness.  Fresh taste and hoppy, but not too bitter.  This is exactly what you want in a beer garden on a warm day.  Oily feel on the palate and average lager carbonation.  Overall, en excellent Euro-lager.  I love to chow down on roasted peanuts and doughy pretzels with mustard while enjoying this brew.

Pilsner malt and a slightly sweet flavor comprise the taste and the aroma. The feel is pretty thin, as expected. This beer is crisp, refreshing and very easy to drink. Pours well and looks the part, good white head sat on top of a golden, clear, clean looking lager. 

To me there is no great smell, just wheat and maybe a hint of summer fruits. 

This is where Paulaner have somehow missed a trick, it doesn’t remind you of Munich or beer gardens at all, it is just a bog standard helles. 

Because I like my beers to be provocative and give me something, this Paulaner produce falls short, in the bottles case anyway. 

I can’t review it from draught because it is some years since I last tried it, but I am sure the scores would have been much higher.

Taste: toasted, buttered white bread, with notes of hay and just a hint of citrus and possibly honey.   Finish: crisp, clean, a little grassy and bready.   Notes: 	Disclaimer:  I like a good lager.  This is a very good lager.  Yeah, it’s not a double-bourbon-barrel-aged, brett-injected, continuously-hopped imperial anything.  What it is instead is a simple, delicious, incredibly drinkable lager done exactly right.  Had five before I realized it.

Pours yellow with small white head that doesn’t last.  Almost no bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is bread, hay, and mild hops.  Taste is water with a sweet malt aftertaste.  Don’t bother with this one.
Domestic swill-like in appearance.  Smells good, somewhat bitter aftertaste.  Decent beer.
as much as i love Paulaner, this is a pretty middle of the road lager. for the price in the states, there are more adventurous lagers out there.
Smells like lager, tastes like lager. Not exciting in any way. Standard German lager

I poured an 11.2oz bottle into a lager glass.

Appearance: Bright maize yellow with slight orange hue. Mostly clear body with some haze. Forms a small, bright white, frothy head which retains and laces very well.

Smell: Generic pale, non-adjunct aroma. Milled grain, slight sweetness and a hint of orangepeel or other citrus pith.

Taste: Pale lagers and pilsners are among my least favorite styles of beer, so if one can make me say anything more than "meh" you know it’s doing something right. That’s definitely the case of Paulaner Lager - I honestly didn’t think I’d like it this much, but it’s pretty good. Up front is a light malty sweetness with a cold, refreshing quality. It’s a clean taste without the oily qualities you tend to get in American adjunct macro lagers. For a moment in the middle there is a quick hop nibble. Just a minute amount of bitterness that you find in pale lagers of the sort. The end finishes much like it begins with a mild sweetness with a hint of orange fruit and orange peel flavor. It’s not necessarily tart or acid like you’d get with a hop forward beer like an IPA, but just much more character than your average pale lager. 

Mouthfeel: Perfectly medium-bodied, actually. Not overly fizzy or carbonated. Refreshing while in the mouth, but it does leave a dry, pasty aftertaste.

Drinkability: I drank Paulaner Lager outside on a hot day and it was surprisingly refreshing. The clean, cold, mild palate really make it a beer to drink for the sake of drinking a beer. While the aftertaste is a little annoying, it’s easily obscured by taking another swig. It weighs in at only 4.9% ABV and satisfies as if it were something heavier. 

Overall, Paulaner Original Munich Lager is one of the best German lagers I’ve ever had.
Draught. Pours a clear golden with a white head. Aroma is cereal and grassy hops, taste is much of the same. Alright.

Bottle at Cloisters. Pours clear a blonde colour with a thin white head. Aroma of yeast, caramel, hay and barley. Flavours of caramel, yeast, barley and wheat with a puffed wheat finish. Little CO2 prickle. Quite a crisp lager. OK.

(bottle) pours a clear yellow colour with a frothy white head. aroma of spicy pale malts, herbal hops, straw and bread dough. flavour is mostly the same, with notes of yeast and herbal hops over a clean, slightly grainy base. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

330 ml bottle @ Cheers in Barcelona. Pale golden body with a nice white head. Light malty aroma with hint of grass. Flavor is soft and refreshing malty with moderate grassy bitterness. Quite ordinary but still decent.
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.

Bought in Porto Alegre; too expensive for what it is; re-drank after many years: Normal appearance, taste is bland, not too much hops, if any; slightly salty, reminds of the taste of the beach sand (minus the crunch), lot of carbonation; medium sweetness, light body, thin feel. Not horrible, not good, just bof.

Originally rated August 2006. Bought at the SAQ in Hull, Quebec. Best before date is 01.07, written in the right-bottom corner of the label. Pours a light golden colour with very little carbonation. The white head is creamy-bubbly and has decent retention. Lace is left and the nose is grassy with some bread and grain. Some light sweetness is in the taste, with the mix of grass and grain again. Hints of hop in the aftertaste. Overall, quite mild and refreshing... and a better alternative to any plain lager.
Bottle 50 cl. Light golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma of malt and grain. The taste is mild and moderately sweet.
On draft at a beach pub in levanto, Italy. Clear golden colour, with a small head. Not that pissy aroma like a lot of pilsners, it’s a bit more agreeable. Nice lager, refreshening.
On draft at the brewery.  Crisp golden color with a classic German white head.  classic helles.  Grainy and refreshing.
Pours a clear golden yellow with a generous white top.  Aroma is mostly grain and a hint of hop.  Taste is crisp, clean, malted and a hint of hop.  Classic helles, no beating it.
Clear yellow with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - straw. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and light bitter finish. 200711
Great Helles, although better from a bottle than canned. The subtile taste is actually really remarkable and it’s nice soft quality is exceptional.

Bottle from Thai supermarket. Clear golden lager body, medium white head. Nose is grains, smooth pale malts and some grassy hop notes. Taste is crisp pale malts, hints of cereals and a clean-cut bitter hop finish. A fairly nice lager beer from Paulaner.
Munich. Golden body with large head. Malty and spicy nose. Taste of malts and some fruits. Dry finish.
This was enjoyed on the trip to München, and unfortunately no written information is preserved.

Bottle. Pours clear golden with a white head that leaves a touch of lacing. Aroma of pale bready malt with floral hop notes and corn flakes. The taste is mild bready malt with a bare minimum of bittering hops. Light bodied and crisp but a little thin.

Nice 30 cl glass on tap at PL brewpub Hamburg. Wonderful fine carbonation and thick-looking golden appearance in glass. Smooth malt edge and honey, very rounded hops. Enjoyed it but yet enough to say.

On tap at Geer Street Garden, Durham. Pale gold pour, fairly vibrant and certainly a full fluffy pour. Nose is soft and faintly floral, not so crisp and hoppy. As a Helles it falls a bit short, in the sense that it’s too mild and unassertive to strike the requisite balance. But as a moderately flavorful quaffer, yeah it’ll do the trick.

Draft at World of Beer (Land O Lakes, FL).  Pour is crystal clear pale golden yellow with a small head that quickly fades.  Tiny bit of lacing along the glass.  Aroma is fairly mild with sweet malt and just a touch of hops.  Crisp, clean flavor that goes down easy.  Mild bitterness in the finish.  A good lager for any occasion.
Had it form a mini-keg. This one is one of the lesser Munich helles beers. It has an off-color and the taste is surprisingly watered down. It is a failure.

Bottle was old and a bit oxidized.  Skunky aroma with a bit of bread.  Pours with a lot of carbonation and a small white head.  Color is yellow.  Taste is crisp and light but the skunkiness overpowers.  A bit of metallic flavor as well.  Pretty light lager and I’m wishing it was fresh as it is probably pretty good.
Pale and headless, very watery, citrusy yet slightly dry, very little taste and overall disappointing

Can 500ml @ home

Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt, grain and light wort. Taste is light to medium sweet. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.

Pours a clear light amber with minimal carbonation and a thinner head that leaves a lace on the glass.  Aroma is a slightly spicy yeast on a malt base.  Tastes largely spicy with sweeter hops and slightly bubbly on the palate.  Sweet hoppy aftertaste.
Clear golden fizzy body with a white head. Aroma of wheat and some caramel. Sweet malty flavour with an underlying bitter tone.

Bottle: &nbsp Clear straw, moreso a yellow, lively carbonation, moderate to large frothy white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Grassy nose, slightly sweet, smidgen of corniness. &nbsp Grassy on the tongue, malty, well at least a decent malt base. &nbsp Smooth, fairly heavy, grassy without much astingency. &nbsp Fairly clean, slightly corny otherwise. &nbsp Moderate fo full body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Straight forward grassy finish. &nbsp Middle of the road, but fairly clean and with a good body. &nbsp Easy sessionable brew.

On tap at The Flying Horse, Stockholm. Aroma is yeasty and slightly roasted. Golden yellow in the glass, quite clear with a high foam. Taste is slightly watery but for a lager it was decent, a little bitter and very refreshing. Mouthfeel is thin with a lot of carbonation.

Paulaner Original Munich Premium Lager has a thick, white head and a somewhat hazy golden appearance, with lots of tiny bubbles streaming up and a good amount of lacing left behind. The aroma is a sharp breadiness, with little-to-no hop smell detected. Taste is a delightful toasted barley, cracker, a subtle hop kiss, and some other subdued, yet indiscernible flavors. Mouthfeel is light and watery, and Paulaner Original Munich Premium Lager finishes crisp, refreshing, and mostly dry. Overall, this is a very good beer. 

RJT

On tap @ Cafe Berlin. Golden yellow, transparent, well carbonated appearance with a foamy two finger white head. Pale grainy, lightly bready, light lager nose with mild German hops. Excellent pale, grainy malty, creamy lager flavor with a nice German hop bitterness. A touch fruity, pale lager finish again with a great hop bite. One of my very favorite helles beers.
Imported from Beerseek, no description given with original rating. Need to re-rate beer.

Chevy Chase Wine and Liquors, DC ($2): Had this a while ago and I don’t know why I didn’t rate it then. In any case, I picked up a bottle just because I like Dortmunders and because I wanted to rate it finally. Pours a golden body with a pretty big white head. Aroma is of dry German hops and grain. Taste has some bitterness that is stronger in the front than in the back. Bready and a little spicy. Really minor aftertaste is left. Really smooth and easy drinking. Extremely refreshing after the first half of my day at work, hehe.
was an ok beer.. was expeciting much more.. taste someone like a saint paulies girl
Bottle - Pours pale yellow with a short lived head.  light malt aroma.  Dry malt hop flavour. dry lingering finish

(12 ounce bottle - Tumbler glass)  Pours a clear yellow color with no head.  Aroma of yeast, light hoppiness and hay bready malt.  Taste of floral hops and dough yeast.  Light body and lively carbonation.
Light straw color; Medium body; Aroma of malt, & some floral hops; Flavor of slight sweet malt, hops, and grain; Palate is a little oily - but good overall.

@ brewpub. Bright yellow-gold with lasting head. Fresh pale malt aroma. Soft palate with lively carbonation. Nice grassy hop profile. Pretty good.
Earlier Rating: 4/16/2010 Total Score: 3
Draft @ Bayernhaus, KL. Chill-hazed dark gold with a tight lasting white head. Aroma is grainy cereal with grassy hop. The low carbonation imparts a smooth palate. Tastes spritzy as if sprinkled with orange. A nice type of acidity. It’s a little thin, and yeastier than expected. Fruity esters linger on the tongue. Not a fave but OK.
Non amo le lager ma questa è godibile e si lascia apprezzare. Tanto malto sia al naso che al palato ma con lievi note luppolate e un finale secco lievemente amarognolo.
50 cl bottle, Sheffield, UK. Medium golden, frothy active head. Sweet cereal aroma with honey and pepper. Ginger like bite on the first sip; mouth filling warmth with a pepper cardamom ending.

Bottle.  Golden with a nice white head.  Spicy hop aroma.  Lovely, grainy malt, lemony, spicy hop flavour and a surprisingly firm bitterness.  Round, smooth, crisp, dry and refreshing.  Precisely why I love German lager.
Pours a dark yellow with a tall frothy white head. Aroma is sweet malt with grass and bread. Taste is some dry hops, malt, straw and bit of spice. Light bitterness. Really smooth. Quite refreshing.

this is the drop that made me fall in love with german beer. i rate this as my favorite beer of all time.  a perfectly balanced beer.  light yet full of character. what all other brewers should use as a benchmark when brewing a lager.

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Lager Glass. Served at cellar temp. Foamy white head. Pours a golden wheat color. Floral and fruity nose. Wheaty aroma. Grass, wheaty, fruity, malt and hop flavors. Wheat taste, very clean. Slightly bitter undertones on palate, but dominated by the sweeter malt. Clean finish. Medium carbonation. It is refreshing, a little lively, and very clean and light. But, it is full of flavor. It is to date the best lager I have ever had. Very well balanced, light and refreshing, and yet interesting enough to want a second.

bottle.  Pours clear pale gold with thin white bubbly head, actually pretty nice lacing.  Classic dortmunder aroma, corn - not in an adjunct way, but in a rich, corn on the cob way - hay, soft but present hops, butter.  Medium to light bodied, crisp and refreshing.  Flavor of buttered corn, some hay, and a lingering finish which is very slightly bitter.  The epitome of a classic lager, unassuming and simple, yet delightful.
Very nice hop bite to it but still very well balanced.  I’ve seen some call this a premium lager, some call it a helles, either way its among the very best german beers out there.

This lager pours a pure white head which dissipates quickly leaving a thin head and some lacing. Color is light yellow. Nose is bready malt. Taste is slight malt sweetness with slight bitterness. Palate is medium light body with a thin texture. The carbonation comes alive on the palate but invisible in the glass. The finish is slightly bitter. This is a light German lager eminently sessionable. Enjoy!

UPDATE 8/27/21
Ten years later the above assessment remains. The "with a thin texture" for the body is nonsense. What was I thinking?

I've upgraded the 3.2 to 3.7 changing Taste and Overall. It remains an excellent lager.  These changes are from a Half Liter can packaged on 2/2/21 with BBY 2/2/22.

Malátás illat, fehér hab ami nagyon gyorsan eltűnik úgy, hogy semmi nem marad belőle. Plusz még buborékok sem szabadulnak felfelé.
Finom száraz, az elején kicsit mézes malátás majd a vég jó keserű ,és komlós. 
Alap sör.

12 oz bottle. Pours clear gold with soapy white head. Aroma of toasted grain and malt, nice mild hop spiciness. Flavor is very much the same. Mouth feel is light body with high carbonation. Overall, a very well balanced, clean tasting lager.
Ero al lago con famiglia e colleghi, e i miei amici si presentano col frigo pieno di codesta dortmunder...Ci stava...

Halvány, sápadt sárga színű, hófehér habja szivacsos és hosszan tartó. Édeskés, eléggé malátás és szalmás illata van. Íze is nagyon malátás, végén érezni azért egy kis virágos komlót. Hosszan tartó, kenyeres utóíze van és száraz. Jóféle, megbízható világos ez, elég könnyű, jól csúszik mellé az étel, ha nem vágyunk semmi különösre, csak egy kis rásegítésre.

12th November 2006 
 Warning! Early amateur rating! Slightly zesty lager and also subtley floral. Otherwise unremarkable. 2.7 

5th May 2015
Bright clear paleish gold beer, small white head. Palate is smooth with very nice super fine carbonation. Clean pale malts, touch of creamy sweetness. Mild floralness. Hops are pretty mild citrus but they do deliver a citric snap at the very end. Clean finish. So very drinkable.

Pretty good. A traditional bavarian offering from Paulaner. Good stuff, taste is right what i expected from a Munich beer.  Overall nice but it only lack a certain something, but I think this recipe has worked for a century they probably wont change it on my account. Anyway wortha try
Can’t believe I’ve never rated this. It’s bottled, it’s grassy, it’s helles. Solid if unspectacular.
Pale yellow colour. Aromas of malts, grass, hops and fruit. Not really the best helles I’ve ever drank.
On tap. Color golden, nice white head. Aroma, fruity, corny. Taste is malty, bready with hints of fruit. Nice bittersweet finish. Drinkable beer.
Nice pale gold with medium head. Sweet malty nose with hints of fruit. Crisp, lively mouthfeel. Sweet malt is balanced by pleasantly soft (but not weak) hops. Enjoyable and refreshing.
Fra dåse, dufter af humle, fremstår flot lys gylden med flot hvidt skum, smager af humle, let fylde , en ok lager.....

Alright, so my hostel in Munich has 8 taps.   Every single one of them is this beer.   Sometimes I just don’t get these people.   Anyway, it’s a great looking beer.   Lots of visible carbonation trails in a bright gold colored body topped with a big and lasting white head that laces the glass nicely.   The aroma is just some clean bready and crackery pils malt.   No real hops to speak of.   The flavor brings in just a light spice from hops and a modest bitterness in the finish balancing a light bready sweetness.   The body is a little on the watery side and carbonation is good.   Clean stuff overall, and obviously brewed to be quite innocuous, though I could drink a lot of this (and did the first night here).   I can’t say that it’s as interesting as Augustiner though.

Pours clear golden with fluffy white head leaving some lacing. Aroma of sweet malts herbs, hay and hops. Pleasant lean-crisp mothfeel. Flavor is fruity, slightly sweet and malty and hoppy. Acidy fresh palate. Finishes sweet and tart hoppy.
Draught at Paulaner’s im Spreebogen (Berlin). Color yellow with medium head. Aroma grass. Taste grass, hop.

Draught at Q-Brick. Fruity aroma, clean and grassy with nice malts. Flavor shows of the malt, yet cardboard comes in big. Nice fruit and grassy hop finish. Much better than the bottle, yet too much cardboard to really enjoy.

33cl bottle. pale gold liquid with rocky white head.
nice fruity aroma, with hints of hops and herbs. taste is characterized by malt and light apple. watery texture, medium carbonation and mellow final.

Perfect pillow of head and very well engineered yellow body. Soft aroma of hops and alcohol. Taste is soft hops with an alcohol finish. A benchmark german lager that can be used as a measuring stick - nice to drink but not particularily exciting.

Bottle. Clear golden yellow with a rocky white head. Aroma of bread and dusty, earthy hops. The flavor is malty without being sweet and a medium hop bitterness. Light body with active carbonation and a crisp dry finish. This bottle was a bit old, but I’ve had this fresh on tap and it is great.
Clear golden with a medium off white head. Somewhat malty nose with hints of cardboard. Flavor had malt, vague hops and cardboard. Finished somewhat dry.

Bottled (from mein-biershop.de). Yellowish golden colour, small head. Aroma is maize, some sweet malts and grains and that’s about it. Flavour is bready malts, some saltwater, mild grains as well as some slight herbal notes.

Draught at Ølbaren.
Clear golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Malty aroma of hay and caramel.
Sweet and malty flavour of hay and caramel with notes of cardboard.
Sweet malty finish.

Bottle 50cl. A clear yellow beer with good carbonation and white head. Smell is on classic lager and nuts. Aroma is relatively sweet and malty, good lager, lightly creamy, nice hopy finish, quite refreshing. Not too bitter, drinkable, body is better than expected, finish has a metallic note.

12oz bottle. A quite clear and light gold body with a foamy white head. Aroma is pretty subdued overall, with a little grass and light malt. Flavor is light and sweet with a small amount of hops and some spiciness. Moderately strong carbonation. Honestly a nice change for a "premium" lager - no skunkiness, no off-flavors, and pretty solid overall, if a little unexciting.
Alla spina al Paulaner’s di Lubeck; non malaccio, se provo a immaginare la versione in lattina in foto....
Light yellow, really nice head.  Light floral aroma with a taste of hops and finish of bitterness.  Nice, easy drinking summer beer.
Bottle 33cl. Blond clear filtered beer with almost no aroma, watery, metallish aftertaste. Pasteurized till death. Sorry, no way!

From a 355ml bottle into a pilsner glass.  Pours a very, very light yellow with little head.  Mild grassy aroma.  Mouthfeel is also very light.  Taste is grass, grapes and a tiny bit of (hoppy???) bite.  Meh, nothing to write home about.

Bottle.
Pale with white head.
Thirstquenching and refreshing brew. Light maltyness. But not much ekse.
Light straw colour. Aroma is of malt sweetness and spicy hops. Light bodied, with a little hop zing towards the end. A little bland, but that is the style. A nice session beer.

Bottle. Nice head and good lacing. To tell you the truth, I just had a bottle of Paulaner Oktoberfest yesterday and now I think Münchner Hell is just a lighter version of that. I’d rather have the tastier one.

Botle at Silenus Pub, Budapest. Pours unclear straw coloured with a small white head. Aroma is weak malty, if i stretch my imagination. Taste is fruity malty with some pleasant sour notes. Easy drinkable.
I find this beer on my trip to Split ..in gas station .. the price 14 kuna (1.9 euro).. in 0,5 litre can .. good beer ..
Bottle. Yellow colour, white head. Malt and yeast aroma, nothing particular. Nothing particular with the flavour either. This is is not a good beer.

Pale gold, clear, thick white head.  Aromas of malt and a sort of forest-y aroma from the hops.  Taste is mild, a bit sweet, a bit bitter.  Light mouthfeel with a slightly dry and sticky finish.  Pretty good light lager, but nothing really stands out about it.
Nothing wrong with this crisp lager.  It is not great, but probably a little too pricey to purchase again in 6’er variety (about $8).  Crisp and solid, but not a stand out by any means.
Well,my least favourite of all the Paulaners.Lacked of the common beer refreshing taste,average aroma,and it’s colour is a vivid yellow that doesn’t quite predispose you for a well drink...
Pours amber with a light head. Aroma and flavor are both pretty much your average munchner/lager. It’s a good blond beer, but still just a blond beer. Nothing special.

Színe tükrös arany, közepes fehér habbal és enyhe/átlagos szénsavassággal.
Illata enyhén gabonás, élesztős.
Csípősen kezd, íze kenyér/kovász jellegű.
A közepe a füves/fűszeres, gabonás aromákról szól, befejezése valamelyest fűszeres, kesernyés és száraz.
A teste nekem picit vékonyka volt, ettől függetlenül ez a sör azt képviselte, amit elvártam tőle, vagyis egy jobbfajta átlagos világos lagert.

Served on draft at Beer Run in Charlottesville, VA on 4/30/10. Pours a clear vibrant golden color with a medium head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of grassy, metallic hops with not much else. The taste is grass, grass and more grass with some faint, lightly toasted malts. Thin-medium bodied. A fairly disappointing beer.
Had this as part of a taste test of the helles from all big 6 Munich breweries.  This took 2nd place over all.  Serving: Bottle
Clear pale yellow, white head, some lacing.  Notes of yeast, banana, and spice.  Tastes of hay and yeast.  Crisp.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a light, straw color with a thin white head.   Bit of a sour, grassy aroma but not a lot to the nose.  Flavor is crisp with a malty finish and some very light grassy hops.  Not a whole lot here but an enjoyable German lager, great for a summer evening.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden colour with a medium white head. Aroma is mostly of sweet malt and grain. A strong sweet honey-ish malt character in flavour but with a noticeable hop presence throughout. Dry finish.
On tap. Grassy, moderate hops. Moderate bitter finish. Pretty much what you’d expect of a German lager, and that’s a pretty good thing.
From a bottle poured a straw color with a fair amount of head.  Grassy malty flavor with a quick finish.

Original Munich Premium Lager--1999	16.9 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  (3.0 / 5.0)  Helles Lager.  Very light clear straw color.  Light hops mixed with German Lager yeast in aroma.  Crisp body has a flavorful light sweet character with a hint of caramel but lacks depth and clings to easy finish.  Sampled 5/6/1999.

Original Munich Premium Lager--2000 16 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  (3.0 / 5.0)  Helles.  Clear light pilsner straw golden color.  Light Saaz front.  Crisp smooth light malt body with Bavarian hint.  Refreshing if light body.  Clean light hop citrus end.  Sampled 7/25/2000.

Bottle 500ml. Pours a clear golden color with a big white fluffy head that disappears quickly. Soft to medium, crisp carbonation and rather light body. Aroma of light grassy hops and grains. Taste is malty, a bit sweet, spicy, crisp and also quite smooth. Very low bitterness, short sweet finish. Overall it’s very drinkable and probably one of my favorite German lagers. Great beer!

Bottle from Kardstadt Dortmund. I figure it’s about time to go through all the Paulaner brews. Got three I’ve not had before...hopefully. This brew wasn’t bad at all. Nice white head that dissipates quickly. Golden color, rather clear with a slight amber hue. Nose is floral with wild daises, grass, and some tulips. Slight hop fill. Taste is decent, light, but well rounded. Bread notes, grains, and slight hops add a clean, refreshing edge. Palate is smooth and creamy. A very decent beer to go through rather quickly.

Bottle, 500ml. Pours a clear golden colour, typical german lager. Large, fluffy, white head that takes a while to disolve. Aroma is faint and mediocre, strong cereal and basment smell. Taste is pretty bad, almost fizzy yellow bad, but with a German lager quality that saves it somewhat. Wouldn’t buy again.

Bottle. Pours a clear straw with with one-finger, bright white, semi-rocky head that has pretty good retention and little to no lace. Aroma is sweet grains, some light fruitiness (apple juice). Taste is sweet, lots of apple juice, honey, some sweet bread rolls, no grassy or hoppy notes. Fairly bland helles but easy session beer. Too sweet for me though.

bottled, crystal clear pale yellow with thin white head, medium grainy malt presence in aroma with slight sour candy-like undertones, no prominent hop aroma, tastes very clean and crisp malt up front and in the finish with no hops standing out, medium body with medium carbonation, very refreshing

On tap at the Esplanade Bier Markt.  My first non-wheat beer from this brewery, and it’s not bad.  Gold, with a medium white head.  Didn’t last, though.  Light, slightly sweet, grainy aroma, with a touch of fruit.  The flavour is a little dryer, and quite simple - grains and noble hops.  Soft mouthfeel.  Not my favourite style, but I could drink a few of these.

500 mL bottle.  Pours translucent gold with a two finger, white head.  Aroma of bready malts, minerals, corn.  Overall flavor is bready and sweet, slightly yeasty, light honey.  Almost a buttery finish which is actually rather pleasant.  Crisp, clean, and easy to drink.  Light bodied with a smooth mouthfeel and a medium level of carbonation.  Subtle and quite tasty, I really like the buttery aspect.  I could drink this all day.

[2805-20100313] Tap. Petrol haystacks and light yeast aroma. Clear, yellow brown body with a long-lasting foamy white head. Not much flavour, just dirty hay and sweet yeast. Medium body. Not my type but fair.

(@ Bier Markt, Toronto, ON)

Bottle.


A - Light yellow with a decent sized bubbly, white head. Average retention with a bit of lacing left.

S - Light with a toasted grain and malt smell. Good amount of bready smell too. A bit of a grassy hop scent.

T - Similar to the nose. Good amount of toasted grain and malt provides the base. Somewhat of a bready taste. Fair amount of floral and grassy hops as well along with a bit of spice. Starts off malty and sweet and finishes with a more crisp bittersweet taste.

M - Light to medium body and decent carbonation. Crisp and pretty smooth. Refreshing but a little thin.

D - Good drinkability. Easy to drink and fairly refreshing. Good light bready flavored beer.

Notes: Somewhat like a lager (especially in the body) but more bready and more hops than the Macros. A little thin for a wheat beer, but good beer.

2010-03-13. Crisp dark yellow body with a nice white head and lace. Flavour has modest bitterness throughout, modest grassy hops, mild pale malt core. Aroma is mild, grassy hops, muted malt. Average palate suits it. Decent mainstream German lager. Quaffable, but a bit dull. Draught at The Bier Markt, Toronto
Light fragrance, clear pour. Very little carbonation and pretty much no head. Tastes great, very smooth with a bit of a slight dry aftertaste. One of my favorites.

Nice aroma of a bit of grassiness, flavour is a light sweet malt upfront with a mid palate of slight spice and finishes with a nice bitterness. Great mouthfeel and one of the better lager’s out there.
Bottle -  Clear yellow/gold. White head. Low to medium carbonation. Thin to medium body. Sweet, bready,  a little citrussy. Pretty average.
Bottle. Pale gold, small white head. Lively, spicy hop aroma. Clean, biscuity malt with a modest spicy hop finish. Light-bodied. Plain but good: it’s balanced and wholesome-tasting.

Bottle. Clear gold, small white head. Crisp, clean, bitter, earthy, grainy, light toast. Finish on the drier side with mild bitterness. Easy drinking helles, have to check on the availability of the tallboys in the picture.

Bottle. Average sized dense foamy white head over a clear effervescent pale straw body. Spicey, floral aroma with hints of bread and honey. A spicey-herbal taste, with a slightly sweet finish. Light bodied.

Bottle brown, 500 ml, got it in Munchen.

Appearance: Pours bright golden, shiny, beautiful and impressive, perfectly clear body, body is very well saturated, carbonation is lively and working for a long time, head is snowy white, initially big, decreasing to small after quick period of time and than lasting firmly for a long time, forthy, leaving nice lacing, texture of the body is characteristically oily as for a typical Helles.

Aroma: Notes of aromatic herbal hoppy top, some notes of lemon and lime, mild and sweetish malty background, some notes of grains but not that pronounced as in German Pilseners, rather not sophisticated and not complex, very streight forward and characteristic of its style, refreshing, again mild and inviting to drinking.

Flavour: Very nice, soft, sweetish, malty frony, some aromatic, fresh, herbal hops are going after highly salty and mineral not only due to its mineral water profile but also due to a high amount of carbon dioxide, interesting and quite easy going, well pronounced flavour of a helles with moderate finish duration, notes of wax.

Pale straw colour with a thin white head.  The nose is clean and crackery with a distinctly minerally crackery note.  Lean and crisp.  It’s simple but it’s pleasant enough.  Quaffable.

bottle: pale, light straw yellow with thin, if foamy, white head. Grassy, yeasty arouma. Smooth, taste. Mildly sweet hops, with some vegetal notes, but not too bad. Well balanced bitterness from the hops. Mouthfeel is a little slippery and medium bodied.

12 oz bottle.  Golden pour with a medium white fizzy head.  Aroma of hops and grass.  Full bodied taste of malt and faint yeast.  Refreshing lager.
Pours a clear golden body with a fading, off-white head.  Smells of clean hops and bread.  Flavor is bready malt with some hops.  Clean finish.

Pours straw colored with a rich and large moderately lasting nicely lacing head. Faint maltiness and hops in aroma. Malty flavor with a dry bitter finish. Overall a rather nice and crisp hot summer session beer.

Small head faded very quickly. Pale golden.
Aroma contains a lot of euro hops, which, unfortunately, can’t quite block out the "dirty alley" and vegetal DMS notes. Quite grainy, not pleasant!
There’s some sweet biscuity malt flavour upon the first sip. After that my brain seemed to realise this wasn’t going to be a pleasant experience, and hence severed all nerves connecting my taste buds. Next to no bitterness, although there is a misplaced lambic-like funky-ness.
Too watery!

I am sorry to say that the dumbed down fizzy lagers of now have smeared the good name of the real golden lager, both of past and of present. Thankfully, there are some who refuse to compromise their principles, standards, tradition, and taste by continuing to brew a tasty lager of quality ingredients and brewing. Paulaner has a long history in Germany, tracing back to the original Paulist himself, Francis of Paola, who started the monastery and brewery. Beer was liquid bread and thus free from the chopping block of fasting, along with being a product they could eventually sell for self-sustaining income.




She pours golden hay with a soft white head resembling cotton fields, their blooms threatening to blow loose in the passing breeze. She sports a lovely white collar, pressed and primped for all to see, while her perfume of honeycomb, soft white bread, white crackers, and green grass are supported by fields of grain basking in the warm summer sun. My first quaff is fresh hay and straw, a brilliant reminder of the cereals and grains of yore that I used to munch on for a fun, tasty snack in-between long bouts playing outside. Her sweet side is a gentle touch of honey with the earthy honeycomb balancing wonderfully with her grainy underbelly. Soft, dry water crackers linger with a delicate dryness of mouth which is easily quenched by another quaff of this fine German lager. I am surprised by her overall soft mouthfeel which shows a snappier side only every now and then with green grass and lemon skins. Clean, tasteful, and easy to session, the Paulaner Lager is an excellent German lager and a fine example of brewing heritage which laughs in the face of conformist mediocrity.




Every now and then I will stumble across a lager which puts a contended smile on my face; the Paulaner Lager was just one of those. It makes all the lackluster lagers before her worthwhile. For one shining moment of inspired satisfaction, my Paulaner Lager bursts with character and flavor.

Bouteille de 330 ml. La bière se présente avec une couleur modeste qui reste. Au nez on découvre des arômes semblable à une pilsner Allemande mais en moins franc, c’est-à-dire du grain frais et du houblon floral. En bouche le corps est mince-moyen et les saveurs sont le grain ainsi qu’une touche fruité et du houblon peu amère. La bière me rappelle la Swiss Mountain en meilleur. La finale est sucrée. This is what lager beer should taste like, floral and clean in body and taste with an inviting hop note.  This is an excellent drinkable helles.

The aroma reminds me somewhat of porridge. Decent and distinctively german. The taste is mainly of pale malt with some lemon sneaking in. The bitterness is quite low. Light bodied. Some goosberries showing up. Melissa and lemon in the finish. Slightly soapy. A very nice lager.

Bottle. Easy drinking, but a little too light all around for a helles. Clear, light golden body with a frothy, white diminishing head. The light aroma presents some toasted grain and a hint of hop. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. The fnish remains lightly bitter with a slight canned corn taste. Medium body with a watery texture, though there’s a stickiness in the finish. The carbonation is lively.

12 oz bottle from Total Wine in Jacksonville, FL.  Bottle marked ’made in 10/07’ on lower right of label.  Pours a nice golden color with a little bit of a head.  Aroma is pine and a bit of honey from the hops.  Taste is hops with a bit of sweetness.  Not bad.
Cask at Zeitgeist @ The Jolly Gardener. Aroma of cream and vanilla, some sweetness and citrus notes. Pours a pale golden beer. Taste is sweet, hoppy with some metal.

As the wife said to me tonight when she brought these back to the hotel room - "I figure we heven’t been through enough Hell today, so why not drink some?"  Pours a bright and clear golden yellow with a slight whispy white cap, minimal lacing.  Aroma is shortbread cookie and gentle hops.  Flavor has a pleasing cookie/biscuit malt and citrusy, slightly lemony, hops.  Light, refreshing and easily quaffable.  Not bad, of course, because its not a Russian beer...

This is a wonderful, full-bodied, well-rounded lager.  It is bright, clear, deep gold with a big white head that slowly shrinks to a smaller lasting head that leaves some lacing.  The aroma is wonderful -  strong, lightly toasted bread, crackers, grain, hints of honey, pine, and citrus.   The taste is similar and also full-bodied, with a lot of toasted grain and bread, hints of hney and pine, but more citrus, especially lemon.  It has a nice full sweetness balanced by a pleasant light bitterness that persists through to the end, with a bready finish balanced with hops.  It is a bit oily, very smooth, and incredible drinkable, with nice subtly complex flavours that persist.
Golden in color and clear with a decent fizzy white head.  Smell is light and malty with a touch of hops.   Taste is much the same as the smell.

light malty smell.  like an american lager without any adjuncts.  taste was a little skunky on the first sip but opened up a light honey banana taste.  refreshing and smooth.  not much of a big deal tho.  I’d probably buy the pilsner instead, but they were on sale and this was the only one I hadn’t tried yet.  all and all a pretty nice brand of beer.  a lot cleaner tasting than some of the other imports.  I would like to try a fresher one of these...  this bottle was born over a year ago

Clear golden color with a fleeting white head. Mild, but nice spicy hop aroma. medium body and smooth. Light flavor is mildly sweet pale malts with a decently bitter spicy hop finish. A good lawn mower brewski here. 9297

Pours a very light, hazy yellow.  I couldn’t really get a feel for the aroma because it was light.  The flavor was pretty OK but it seems to be more like a glorified pale lager.  I like the other Paulaner beers better.  I drank this out of a lager glass.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Yellow gold with lasting ring.  Bread honey and lemon aroma.  Very mild honey flavor, mild spiciness without much finish.  Smooth and clean but less complex than other lagers.  Medium-light body, medium carbo.  Pretty decent.

Bottle 330ml. Poured pale gold with the slightest haze and a rocky, off-white head which was average lasting. Aroma was of sweet grainy malts with very light hoppy notes, straw, light notes clove and hints of lemon citrus. Flavor was a very mild bitterness with notes of sweet wholegrain bread, hay, light notes of honey, hints of lemon, the slightest suggestion of dried pear and a clean finish. Light bodied with medium carbonation, a watery texture, thin mouthfeel and a short length finish.

1 pint, 9 fl. oz bottle.  Pours a pale golden yellow.  Flavor: Hints of corn and rice, with very little hops.  (Then again, my palate might be spoiled because I’m all about hoppy IPA’s.)  Overall, this one is perfect for a hot summer day....right after mowing the lawn or hosting a backyard barbeque.
Classical german hell. Bright yellow color with a nice white head. Malty aroma. Light sweetness, medium bitterness. Just fine for drinking more than one.

Bottle: Pours a transparent light light yellow. Bubbly with a thin head. Earthy grain aroma, I also get some corn, maybe some rice. Tastes of fresh cut grass and hops. Some white bread is also present. The palate is thin, but well balanced and smooth. Tasty indeed.

Bouteille de 330 ml, acheté à l’SAQ de Centropolisse (Laval) le 22/2/08, bu ce soir. Blonde claire, un peu de collet. Arome d’houblon très sec, céréal malté faible. Goût légèrement malté, un peu de céréal mi-croustillant, peu d’arrière goût. Rien de spectaculaire, juste buvable!
Bottle. Pours a pale yellow colour. Very thin on the nose, a bit malty. Flavour is a bit malty with very light bitterness. I don’t know. I did not like this one, way too thin in several ways...
A sweet and wide malty bavarian taste. Quite smooth. Looks clear and golden. Not bad at all.
Bottle @ Dos in Davis. Had this brew next to another lager, and paled in comparison.  The experience was smooth going in, but most was aftertaste that lingered.  I wasn’t impressed.
Poured a golden color and had a very grainy smell. Flavor is back loaded with a slighty bitter kick for the aftertaste. Not bad, but an average beer.

Drank this out of the bottle so color and pour not in the picture. It had a weird herby grain off flavor in the start. Let it sit a few mins and it turned into a fairly drinkable European lager. Not great but better than the typical American macro swill to be sure.

(on 33ml. bottle, never seen such a small bottle from this brewhouse) So, best sold lager in the world, well, about time I taste it, then. Pale yellow, nice, lasting white head. A small hoppy nose, in fact the hops are the dominat aroma and flavour throughout the drink, even though I suspected more breadyness. Fresh carbonation, goes well with the rather dry and herbish finish. I liked it.

On tap at the Castle. Served in a really nice Paulaner mug. This is definitely quite an enjoyable brew, from one of my favourite styles. It’s a bit mellow, but still with enough sweet biscuity malts to satisfy my palate. The mouth-feel is very decent, smooth, crisp, refreshing. The only thing it really loses points for with me is the fact that it has just a touch too much hops than what I like to have in my Dortmunders and Helles lagers. But over-all, when served fresh this is a great example of a simpler, but delicious style of beer!

Bottle. Tanx to Tjalve.
Light clear golden and a white head. An ok pils with some fresh hops and citrus. Also some metalic feel in aroma and taste.

Pours a light clearish yellow color with a thin white head that dissipates quickly. Smells of grains and straw. Nice and clean and crisp. Along with the nice crisp clean malty flavors I get a little banana as well. Thin palate, but it coats the mouth a bit as well. Carbonation is less prominent than I expected from a lighter colored beer.
This is a nice, light German brew, lager, whatever.

Clear golden yellow with a foamy white head. It has a hay-like malt aroma and slightly hoppy. Flavor is obviously very malty with some fruit notes and grainy, pleasant bitterness. Medium body and lively carbonation.

On tap at The Castle on King- Pours a sparkling gold liquid capped with a thick foamy froth, leaving good lace. The aroma is subtle grass, hay, some wood, and a touch of malty lemony goodness. The flavour profile is cookie/biscuit upfront with hay/lemon mid way and finishes with a good fresh hop lemon profile. Nice bite to the finish. Subtle and enjoyable session beer.

On tap:

Puts a clear pale gold lager in the glass with a 2 finger white sticky cap moderate retention, reduces to a surface cap and laces well.

Aroma of fresh biscuits with a herbal-woody   under tone.

Stable malt spine, some biscuit malt up front, lovely herbal-woody-lemony discernment in the middle then a nice biscuit snap at the finish balanced with more earthy notes.

A fine helles for sessions...I think I like this better than the Hacker helles.
12 oz bottle pours a nice golden yellow with tight foamy head, some spice and yeast, a nice everyday lager
Nice grainy flavor with a bump of hops on the finish.  Clean tasting and quite drinkable.

12 oz. bottle poured into lager glass- poured transparent golden yellow, white head formed and slowly bubbled away.  Aroma of malt, grains, and hops.  Hits the mouth with a defined thin body, malt and hops noticeable but not overpowering, finish melts away, very refreshing.
A very good lager on tap and better than average in a bottle. Very crisp and slightly hoppy...overall pretty good for a lager.
Pours golden with a white head.  Aroma has a light hoppishness and very little malt.  Flavor is crisp and clean with a nice touch of the hops.

16.9 oz bottle-A clear golden body with a small white covering for a head. Aroma of grains, malt, and a little hops. Taste of grains, yeasty, bread like with a little dryness on the back end. An easy drinking brew.
Wait for the foam, wait for it. Ok. A clear straw yellow lager with lots of bubbles. Smells like sweet grain. Earthy, musty. Light, hoppy taste.
On draught at Zur Brez’n - Munich, pours a clear gold with a white head. Medium body, mellow hops crispness dominates flavor profile. Nice!

Bottle. Small white head, Golden color with a clear liquid. Light aroma with a bit malt and bread, like the flavor but medium. litlle hop flavor and light bitter. The finish is a light bitter and medium.

330ml bottle. 

Pours a burnt gold with a small white head. Smell is grassy and earthy with a fair helping of skunk. Taste is sweet and grainy. Simple and average lager but not offensive, just not great.
Pours a nice head with a gold colour.  Very natural but not overpowering.  A good quencher. Recommended.

500ml. Golden in color with lots of carbonation.  huge fluffy pillowy head stands very tall, well retained, and quite attractive.  light grainy aroma. simple clean lager with noble german hops providing a solid bitter finish. well rounded medium body with just a touch of sweet grain. leaves thick pasty lacing. pretty good.
Slightly fruity aroma.  Flavor is light, balanced with a bit of fruit and malt.  Not bad but a bit plain.
A dull beer with little life to it. I didn’t like it at all. The old ball and chain couldn’t even finish her glass. I found it it rather unmanly.

Had thid beer on 5/5/1999.  Color is a light, hazy gold with good carbonation and light head.  Aroma is very light, but a thin scent of malt is there.  Taste clean and smooth.  It starts with a light crisp body that goes smooth as silk with a light malt bite.  The finish is a sweet malt flavor with light hop character and a mild light hop bitterness.

pours clear yellow with a small white head, good lacing.
smell is wheat, some hops, dried hay, malts.
taste is on the sweet side, bread dough, grainy, ends bitter and dry.
this beer actually grows on you and gets better as you partake.

Bottle: produced 08/07 - pours a clear pale yellow-straw with a white head that collapses to a thinny, 
many small streams of bubbles work their way up as it waits for me to sniff and take a sip,
has malt, bread and sweet fragrances with a faint flower-grass hop aroma, faint grain fragrances, clean and straight forward aromas,
sip has a taste of some malt and faint sweetness that is fleeting, light bitterness on the tongue comes in to balance, 
not lots of flavor but not flavorless either, has a medium mouth feel, light on the palate, finished is pretty dry that leaves some bitterness,
I would love this beer with pizza.

Poured a clear golden yellow with a decent foamy white head that slowly disapated. It had a slight citrus aroma. There was a nice crisp clean taste but not much as far as flavor. There was a little bitter bite at the finish. I hoped the beer tasted as good as it looked in the glass.
On tap at Paulaner Munich on our honeymoon.  Pours a hazy yellow with a white head.  Light aroma of sweet and grainy malt.  Sweet clean flavors.  Citrus and yeast.  Lightly dry in the finish. Decent.
Bottle. Nose is biscuity grains. Solid flavor but uncomplex. Somewhat rough palate with a dry finish.

Clear golden yellow lager-ish color with a foamy white head.  Pretty bland and predictable grainy, slightly skunky aroma with a hint of hops.  Flavors were similarly grainy with a pretty decent hoppiness.  Very bready characteristic.  Medium carbonation, pretty light-bodied, nearly watery.  Nothing special, but I wish I saw BMC drinkers having these now and again...
Weak aroma, taste, not so great, better than budweiser, but not by much...  I think it may be a tad bit overrated on this site.

Pours a clear, medium straw hue with a short, yet creamy, white head that quickly fades.  Aroma most definitely of Weetabix and grass clippings, light overall, with perhaps a touch of honey.  The flavour is very mild, with some very light pear-like acidity.  Bready sweetness finds its way out at the finish, the initial taste being rather devoid of everything.  The finish also holds a slight oily grassiness, but it’s not much and does little to please.  Light bodied with moderate carbonation and a watery, empty mouthfeel.  Lacks everything that can make a Helles interesting.  50cl can, Leffe goblet, bbe 06.08.

Tap. Aroma was light all around. Cereal for the malt, grain and grass for the hops, and dough and earth for the yeast. The head was small, white and fizzy which mostly diminished but left fair lacing. Color is sparkling clear gold. Flavor starts lightly acidic and finished lightly bitter. Body was light to medium, texture was dry/watery and had a fizzy carbonation. Overall a tastey beer and pretty much a standard for German Helles.

Bottle date 07/07; really fresh.  Pours a pale yellow with a thick whipped egg white head.  Aroma is sweet malt and fresh bread.  Taste is sweet pale malt with some slight maple syrup notes and mild hoppiness.  Very good South German helles; for those who prefer a pale lager slightly maltier and less hoppy than a pils.

0.5 l can. Pours crystal pale yellow body with small head. Sweetish grainy aroma, too much... Flavor quite well balanced not bitter not sweet. Light bodied, with watery texture leaves medium a bit bitter finish. Nothing special, expected much more.

Bottle, Aikmans, St Andrews. Gold, thin white head. Nose is malty, maybe just a hint of grassiness. Mouth is fruity hops, with some generic bitterness sneaking in and dominating. Pretty good, but nothing special from a macro.

Bottle 500ml. Golden color with a thin White head that disappear quickly. Malty Aroma with notes of hop. Flavor is refreshing and finish a little bitter...

Cerveja Dourada com uma espuma fina que some rápido. Aroma maltado com notas de lúpulo. Sabor refrescante e amargo no final.

Poche pippe, storia o non storia: la Paulaner Hell, oggi, non è molto diversa dalle sue colleghe nello stesso stile di Spaten, Riedenburger, Bitburger, Hacker-Pschorr, Hofbrauhaus e chi più ne ha più ne metta; lo ’scarto’ è il solito scarto Paulaner, soprattutto nell’aroma, che comunque rimane abbastanza deludente. Bottiglia da 33cl comprata a prezzo stracciato (neppure un euro) all’Iper di Serrapalle Scrivia; versata nel bicchiere è di una chiarezza e di una trasparenza limpida, con schiuma generosa ma poco persistente. Il maltato carico e fragrante dell’aroma si conserva nel sapore, poco bilanciato con note di luppolo evanescenti. Buonina, ma vale il discorso di sopra.______________ENGLISH TEXT HERE______________Less pipps, history or not; Paulaner Hell, today, is not very different from its colleagues in the same style from Spaten, Riedenburger, Bitburger, Hacker-Pschorr, Hofbrauhaus and anyone can add names; the difference is the usual Paulaner difference, especially in the aroma, which this time remains a bit disappointing anyway.33cl bottle bought at a good price at the Iper supermarket in Serrapalle Scrivia; pours a very clear yellow transparent liquor, with generous white head. Sweet malts in the aroma and flavor, which is badly balanced with too little hoppy bitterness. Nice, but nothing special.

Draught at Paulaner im Roten Ochsen in Cologne. Golden beer with a medium, short-lasting, white head. Both the aroma and the flavor are mostly malty but with a bit of hops presence as well. The body is surprisingly medium to full, and the mouthfeel is quite nice.

Name: Paulaner

Date: 03/12/1998

Source: Wild Wing Cafe, Marietta



clear yellow, lots of visable carbonation, sweet malt aroma, frothy head, tart malt flavor, slight clove character, 



Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20

Rating: 2.6/5.0
Score: **/4

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.
Clear and yellow. Has a white head. Mostly lasting. Light aroma, some hoppy notes. Flavor starts moderate sweet and finish moderate bitter. Watery texture.

Golden/yellow poure lots of bubbles and a medium white foam head.  Bready aroma, little citrus.   Flavor is clean and glassy, slightly on the yeasty/malty side.  Hops appear in the aftertaste.   Watery palate dispite the bubbles.  
The maltiness makes this a good pizza beer =)

12 oz, bottled Dec 2006. Clear topaz with a small, but lasting head. Dry, sweet cereal and corn shuck-grassy aroma. Flavor is sweet cereal grain, with some delicately bitter, fruity and herby hops on the end. Palate is almost medium-bodied, fairly smooth and makes my tongue tingle a bit.

My bottle says Original Munich premium lager, I hope this is the right beer. Initially an off aroma when you pop the lid but it clears to a more attractive olfactory once poured. Ubiquitous pale yellow american lager color. The taste is a little more savory than many dorts. Some salt in the background. Much easier to enjoy without effort when compared to 	Great Lakes Dortmunder Gold and Victory V.  Good creamy carbonation is present on a medium low level.  Bitterness is well controlled and minimized. But after a few swigs and near the end of the session there is a building industrial or mettalic bite that manifests itself on the back of the throat. That hangs for a while on the finish. Overall, cannot keep up with that ever popular dort Lowenbrau.

Bottle, 500ml, pasteurised. Gold with white  forced head. Thin and watery malt flavours straight from the start with quite a metallic, tinny background taste. I get a touch of hops, but seemingly quite boiled and I get very little subtle nuances, frankly disappointing.

Bottle... very impressive beer. Was interested in it after it’s debut with me was a Salvator. Pours a nice and soothing yellow with a medium sized white head. First impression: might have a bit of a watery, generic flavor. On second time around, an instant change. A very full bbodied flavor. Textured, with character. The finish is nice and hoppy. A beautiful bitter flavor. A very fine beer.

Newly distributed beer, Bottle date of 02.06, Sampled August 2007

Pours a brilliantly clear, yellow gold color and is topped by a frothy, initially fat, one-finger thick, pale, off-white colored head.  The aroma has a sharp, herbal grassiness to it that is immediately noticeable.  Underneath this is a nice, dry, biscuit / cracker like malt character, but there is also a touch of sweet grain aromatics here as well.  Hints of butterscotch and a touch of lemon zest are also noticeable at times in the aroma.



The beer is quite chilled right now, which causes it to be quite crisp, with a biting bitterness and a cracker-like malt character.  At this temperature the beer is quite dry.  As it warms up a bit a soft, though simple, malt sweetness becomes present as does a touch of butterscotch.  The hop character opens up a bit more; it leans towards grassy notes with perhaps a hint of lemon zest.  The perception of bitterness really is muted once the beer warms up as well, though it still provides a sharp backbone to the flavor profile.  Somewhat light bodied, but still has a touch of structure and body to it.  A decent beer, which is probably even better fresh.

Bottle. Disappointing after the hefeweizen, but hard to be otherwise. Decent enough, with a subtle sort of oaky flavour. That’s all gone by the time the bitter finish arrives though, so you’d have to say the timing’s a bit off. Carbonation is somehow weird as well.
Bottle. Golden coloured with a decent white head. Sweet malt aroma with some zest hops. Flavour also had a sweet edge with a slightly bitter finish. Ok.

Bottled over a year ago (oops), I was surprised how good this one was. Pours a clear yellow with a spare, almost creamy, white head. On the nose is a sweet grain (corn) and straw with a bit of skunk on the pour that fades with time. Light-bodied and lively with a dry, clean finish. There was a hint of metal in the first few sips, but it disappeared by the third or fourth. Sweet, bready malt with a hint of corn. Crisp, clear and refreshing. This is definitely a good candidate for a BMC drinker’s "gateway" beer. Familiar enough for pale lager fans to be comfortable with the flavor profile and then get them to try Paulaner’s pils, hefe and marzen. If AB could make a beer like this, I’d buy it.

Sweet malty smell - a little too much and pungent for me. Average light golden color - nothing extraordinary.  A little off on the carbonation and slightly watery - but decent.  Very easy to drink.  Short, bitter bite in the aftertaste - I enjoy this short finishing bitterness.  The more I drank of this and let it sit, the more the flavors stood out and developed in the glass.

mildly tropical fruit flavors co-exist with this german type bitter and refreshing brew. with small carbonation and a lightish mouthfeel this is a beer you can sit back and break open a few times! once an interesting challange to reveal (before american brewers did all of the work for the taster). this is a nice example of a spicy and subtle beer.

Pours slightly light golden with decent quickly fading head.  Smell is a nice mix of light hops, and malty sweetness.  Taste is honey malt sweetness, light to medium bitter hoppiness.  Slightly thin with a minimal malty yeast finish to it.  Overall this is very drinkable.  A very beery beer, and enjoyable although not really unique.  Kind of Pilsner like, I thought, and I could drink this again.

Can. Pours a golden colour with a good fairly lasting white head. Aroma of malt, grains and bit hoppy.  The flavour has a good maltiness with some graininess, some sweetness and some hoppiness. Hvala Ognjan.

Bottled. beer is clear, light yellow-gold with a small, white, frothy, mostly and quickly diminishing head.The aroma is is malty with a light note of toasted grain; Hoppy with light notes of lemon zest, herb.The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, trace/lightly acidic with an average-length, lightly bitter finish.The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

Clear gold, decent white head. Bready malt aroma, slightly sweet. Malt cereal palate, some reedy hop character to finish that begins as fairly subtle but shows itself as perfectly balanced as the pint gets lower in the glass. Medium heaviness for mothfeel. I had several of these tonight and enjoyed them.

Bottle 0.33L.
Clear golden body with an average, frothy, white head, mostly diminishing with a good lacing.
Moderate hoppy aroma (flowers, citrus) with a light malty character; fruity notes, maybe pineapple.
Moderate bitter-sweet flavour: well balanced.
Light-to-medium body with a watery texture; lively carbonation; light metallic feeling in the finish.
Nice lager beer.

On tap in a beach bar at Jurmala, Latvia. Pale golden colour, moderate head. "Neutral" aroma. Clean flavour, with a moderate hoppy bitterness on a pleasant but very moderate malty base, with some nice notes of fruit (pineapple). Easy drinking.
Unter den Linden, Berlin. Flavorful but watery. Malt...............................Saborosa mas aguada. Malte.

Aroma of sweet malt, a little grassy, and some lemon. Pours a pale gold with a soapy white head that stays for a little while. Flavor is initial malty sweetness followed by a lemon hop flavor that is rather strong. Crisp and citrusy. A nice thirst quenching lager.
Good light, pilsner colored lager. Available at our local german joint, the Student Prince.

Bottle 0,5l at Viktualienmarkt München 18 Jun 07. Pale golden/ yellow coloured. A tiny white head. Metallic aroma. Dry fruity flavor of grapefruit. Dry sweet aftertaste. An OK thirst quencher.  Hoppy impression throughout.

Bottle. Pours a pale gylden with a big fizzy but quite creamy white head. Aroma is quite powerful with lots of sweet malts and a lemony hoppyness. The flavour expands on the lemony note. Begins quite sweet, but turns towards a quite citric bitter finish. An acceptable thirst-quencher.

Sampled with Finn from a 500ml bottle at Viktualienmarkt, München. Golden body with good white head retention. Flavour of hoppy fruits and ripe grapfruits, but not particular refreshing. Dry ending. Thin bodied and a bit overcarbonated (18.06.2007).
Traditional German lager, malty and smooth with light hops. Very drinkable and enjoyable.
I’d have to say that is this my favorite lager.  That’s why it gets a perfect score.  I had it with my friend in his backyard.  Great hoppy taste, just awesome

Subtle bready notes in the nose.  Pours a sparkling clear straw.  The mostly lasting white creamy head is super sticky & stiff like meringue, and leaves behind light lace.  The flavor is typical of a lager; well balanced but non-descript.  Light acidity leads to a grainy finish.  The light & creamy body is soft.  To be enjoyed with food.  Labelling this a Dort/Helles is a stretch IMO, this brews profile fits much more comfortably in the Lager category.

Tasted 22/06/2007. 500ml bottle from Regional Wines and Spirits.  Slow cooked on the way out to NZ.  The nose was all cardboard, boiled sweets and veges. In the mouth it was fizzy, lightweight, watery and stale. Unfortunate but a beer this subtle is never going to make much of a traveller.

I didn’t much care for the aroma of this one.  On the pour, small head, transparent color.  Unpleasant small.  First taste is a little on the skunky side.  I don’t know if I got an old bottle or not, but it sure tasted skunked.  It still had an obvious Paulaner taste, but pales in comparison to the quality of the heffe.
Tap: Clear light gold/yellow with stable fine white head. Malty hoppy aroma and taste. Medium bodied. Fresh & crisp. Rather simple but all around very drinkable & pleasant.
Bottle Pours a straw yellow color with a decent white head. Aroma of grass, malt, and some hops. Flavor of sweet malt with a light hop finish.

Draft at Die Bierstube. Crystal clear honey gold with scant white head and lace. Rich forward funky nose; sweat-socky, cardboardy, and lightly sour. Light carb, watery body, light hay/sweat/foot on the mid-palate. No finish. Not a hell of a lot of a beer here.
surprisingly good malt driven lager, Firm malty nutty base with a surprisingly dry finish excellent nose, it was a pleasure to drink

Bottled.
Golden with a large, rocky, white head.
Grassy hoppiness in both aroma and flavour, but with some wet cardboard aswell.

Rated 1/27/07:  Sweet grainy aroma, pretty subdued. Light golden pour, mild head with some minimal lacing and nice steady carbonation. Crisp with a touch of sourness to the mouthfeel, rather refreshing. Nice taste, lightly hopped to a light malt content. Sweet and grassy, it’s tasty but I enjoyed the Harp I had prior to this much more.

330 ml bottle, best before 11.07. Pretty sure the NSLC got this as a mistake, as they normally only have the hefeweiss. Pale golden colour with a mostly lasting creamy and fizzy white head. Biscuit, floral, herbal, and grassy aroma. Cereal and bready malts with a pleasant grassy and lightly herbal and pefumed bitter finish. Light bodied, quaffable and refreshing. The drinkability does wonders for this.
12oz- Nice, crisp Eurolagar.  Very light malt flavor with plenty of hops.  Nice but indistinguishable.
Light fruity aroma, pours a slightly hazy yellow, with a very small, quickly fading head.  Very smooth flavor, slightly sweet with hops balancing on it.  Very crisp, and nice for summer.

in can 350 ml.
(brewed and canned in Chile)
Pale yellow color. Small and very gaseous head. A good aroma, candy, with something of herbs. In paladar, in the beginning, it is very sweet (the caramel is very well-known). It finishes pleasantly, with nice hoppy. The body is very light, much. It is a good standard beer, no more.

bottle. Lovely pale gold color with a full size white head and decent lacing. Fairly average hop aroma like your typical lager. Starts with a sweet tang then reveals the ginger spice that it promises. Light hop finish. The color and spice make this lager a refreshing and pleasant beer.
I really like their weiss beer, so I decided to give this a try.  Poured golden yellow.  Not bad, but no real characteristic that stood out. Very drinkable, however.

Straw to gold coloured with a rapidly receding head. Faint grainy aroma, but still in a good way, really. The taste has also some grainyness but different from other beers I’d describe in that way. Better finished really. Thus the malts are rather dry and the hoppiness light but not at all nonexistent.

Still, it’s probably among the more pleasant beers of the light lager persuasion (light lager not meaning light light if you know what I mean) I’ve had. Fresh tasting and pretty faultless, which can’t be that easy to achieve in a beer like this.

Class act really and objectively it should maybe have scored higher. In the end though, I’m not very likely to seek this out. Perhaps I’ll think of some food pairing that requires a light lager and then this will definitely be on my short list.
Draught: Poured a golden yellow with a white color head. The aroma was harvest and corny. The flavor matched perfectly, very taste, and fresh.

Bottle. Sort of grainy aroma backed by some hop. Rather non-descript, but at least it does not smell like corn. Brassy color with a white head that tries to lace. Starts a bit thin, grainy, grassy. The saving point is that there is some hop. The finish is relatively dry, and the hop lightly dominates. Not all that bitter, except compared to the evil Bud! I’d drink it, if no ale whatsoever were available. It is kind of growing on me.

Poured medium golden with a nice frothy long-lasting head.  The nose had a just barely discernible skunkiness but after the first drink I didn’t notice it anymore.  This is a pretty bitter and  medium bodied  lager, a fairly typical Bavarian beer.  Works for me.
Bouteille. Arome de grain faible. Couleur or clair. Mince mousse qui se dissipe lentement. Goût bien malté, finale légèrement houblonné. Effervescence moyen, corps moyen. Bonne lager.

Bottle. Light-gold in color, with a fluffy white head that seems to dissapate quickly. Malty, light-bodied beer. I like German lagers and this is a pretty good one. A very good summer beer because it is not too heavy. Yet, it has way more flavor than American mega-brews. Nothing outstanding, just a good German lager.
Good helles. Nice sweet malt flavor with a touch of spice. Well carbonated, refreshing...
I like this lager. A nice sweetness with a touch of spice. A distinctive aroma for a lager - at least it is there - unlike most other lagers.
subtle, spicy, naturally hearty taste.  nice kick to it.  well carbonated.  would definitely try it again.  Have to try the paulander wheat beer now.
Pours clear golden with no head. Mild carbonation. Mild grassy aroma. Flavor is fairly malty, more than I was expecting from this light beer. Light bitterness. Metallic aftertaste. OK.

12 oz. bottle- color of golden yellow , with a frothy white head - nose of  hay , grass , mild floral hopps , malt , and slight skunk  – taste of bubblegum , sweet malts, and light hopps - body smooth , crisp , and medium carbonation – aftertaste of grassy , and slight resin

The one I had at the Seehaus in Munich was memorable not because of the beer but the beautiful location and the great meal we had. Also had this in a can late at night in the main Munich subway station and not so memorable. Page 354 of Michael Jackson’s Great Beer Guide and only 298 of his 500 Classic Brews to go.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass, golden with a medium white head. Aroma was very faint with a touch of malt and grain. The taste was like a lightly malted mineral water. Not really to my taste, but not offensive in any way.
A nice lager. Aroma is a little weak, but expected from a Lager. Appearance is pour. Very clear and pale yellow. Mouthfeel is very smooth and flavor is bland. A decent brew.
Pours a pale yellow with no head to be found.  More bitter than sweet with a hint of fruit.  Mellow, very smooth and honestly, kind of boring.

appearance: golden yellow. perfectly clear. huge fluffy white head. constant 

up-stream of carbonation.
smell: lemon, a little malt
taste: a little soapy, but mostly pretty good.
mouthfeel: oh so smooth.
drinkability: very easy to drink.
overall: one of the better lagers i’ve had.

Boa cerveja alemã. Sabor levemente amargo, sem muita acentuação, tendo o seu final também amargo. coloração amarelo clara, igual a uma pilsen premium brasileira. O cheiro é fraco, igual a um chopp aguado. É uma cerveja refrescante, sem sabor adocicado, tem persolnalidade, forte, mas nem tanto quanto outras Munchners.

Pours a pale yellow color w/ a medium semi creamy froth w/ tight spatter. Aroma is malty w/ muted grains and hay. Light nectar w/ mellow residual effers. Flavors are muted and not very defined. Malt and grass w/ a mellow finish. Mild skunk.
Golden yellow beer with short-living egg-white head.  Taste is somewhat bitter.  OK lager with food.

Bottle. Pours a very nice golden yellow with a nice, dense foamy head. Aromas of slightly sweet malt and a bit of hops. Smooth, thick mouthfeel with a good amount of banana esthers. Some lime aftertaste and again some sweet malt in the background.

Bottled. Tasted in Belgian Dash beer store, Goiânia, Brazil. Pours golden color with a creamy head. It´s a medium bodied german blonde with a lot of personality. Malty aroma. The taste is strange for brasilians, - accustomed with watery "pilseners" - with hay, yeast and malt. Dense bready Mouthfeel, lightly sweetness.
Nice light gold colour with a small layer of foam. Quite sweet and crisp. It’s pretty good.

Tap, Cape Of Good Hope, Oxford. Light gold, small white layer of foam, nice ring of lace. Light bready aroma. Suffers a bit from being served really cold. Bright carbonation, malty warmth, just a touch of earthy hops in the finish. Light and refreshing palate, without being unsubstantial. Overall good, but a bit muted. Just a very small flavor impact.

500ml bottle from Tesco. Pale straw with a fine thick white head, a steady bead and it leaves a good lace too! Average nose of malt’n’hops. It’s quite smooth and slghtly sweet, with a medium body. Good,if a tad on the uninspired side.

0.5 L Bottle. Medium-sized lasting creamy head. Nice amber color. Smell is light maltiness. I had it at a temperature that was just a bit colder than lukewarm, which I think made many different flavors come through. Quite a sharp, spicy bite of hops for a lager, perfectly balanced by a doughy, mild malt flavor.  Very good representation of  the style.
Easy drinking lager. Little bit of a buttery nose and taste. Quite good, yet nothing very rememberable. I maybe like this better than the pils-type german beers.

On draught at The Old Monk, Westminster. Pale gold colour. Fairly standard Helles with soft bready malt and light grassy hops on the nose. Much the same in the flavour, with just a little bitter hop bite. Smooth and easy drinking. Noticeably fresher and cleaner than the Hacker-Pschorr Helles sampled just before.

I smuggled a .5L from Germany.  Bright golden yellow color.  Very thin white head.  Smells like a can of corn nibblets.  Tastes like malt and a smooth hop finish.  Not my favorite Münchner Hell, but still reminiscent.

Bottle. Pours light yellow with a small but tight white head. The aroma is sweet, almost like brown sugar, and grass. The flavor is lots of grass with some sweet tones and even a bit of tea. It’s ok, but definitely not my thing.

Golden color out of the 12 oz. bottle with a fluffy white head.  Yeasty nose with some buscuit.  Very good with a sausage and kraut meal.  Bready malts with subtle citrus flavors.  Tastes like most imported European lagers.  Best with food.

Stein at Oktoberfest Bar in Fulham (London), clear light copper with a large white foamy head. Grassy hop aroma but with some fruity notes. Quite smooth with a light mouthfeel, bitter dry palate along with some sweeter notes. Pretty good.

Bottle from Hy-Vee Liquors poured into lager glass - Pours gold with a 2 finger off white head and very lively carbonation; Malt, hops, light caramel and something I simply can’t distinguish to the nose; Malt, bread, very light hops, some spice on the initial taste; Bready, lightly spicey backtaste; Good carbonation that doesn’t get in the way, medium-full palate; Bottle is labeled Original Munich, obviously the English translation. Overall, not too shabby. I was pleasantly surprised by this brew. Drinkable. Doesn’t assault you with flavor, just kind of refreshes you. Nice when you’re just looking for a decent beer to quench your thirst. Price to quality ratio is a bit lopsided in my region though. Not the best from Paulaner, but definitely nothing to pitch down the drain!
